title: Calling `push` on wrapped array returns unexpected results.
body:
While migrating to 3.1.0 I encountered some unexpected results, specifically:

``` javascript
var wrap = _([])
wrap.push(1).push(2)
wrap.value()
// => []
```

I expected push to mimic an arrays native push function, updating the existing array. But we'll just reassign `wrap` and move on

``` javascript
var wrap = _([])
wrap = wrap.push(1).push(2)
wrap.value()
// => [1, 2]
```

Everything seems fine now, until performing an operation on the reassigned wrapped array.

``` javascript
var wrap = _([])
wrap = wrap.push(1).push(2)
wrap.find({})
wrap.value()
// => [1, 2, 1, 2]
```

``` javascript
var wrap = _([])
wrap = wrap.push(1).push(2)
wrap.find({})
wrap.find({})
wrap.value()
// => [1, 2, 1, 2, 1, 2]
```

I'm not yet familiar with how 3.x.x works to tackle this one, but I'm looking forward to the PR that addresses it.

title: Binding all predicates in all functions to specific this object
body: Most of lodash function can accept an optional argument [thisArg] allowing to bind the predicate. Is there any way to implicitly bind this to all of the predicated in functions in lodash object or single chain wrapper object. I thought  that `_.runInContext` can be used, but it exists for other purpose.

title: Allowing passing arguments to _.attempt'ed invocation
body:
Would it be possible to change the signature of `_.attempt(func)` so that any arguments after `func` would be passed to the invocation of `func`? i.e. exactly as you can `_.defer(func, "hello")`.

Looking at [the source](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/3.1.0/lodash.src.js#L10163), the extra arguments aren't currently used in any way, and consistency with other auto-invoking methods would be nice.

title: FEATURE REQUEST: _.setTimeout and _.setInterval
body:
When writing coffeescript, `setTimeout()` and `setInterval()` look terrible, i.e.

``` js
setTimeout (argument) ->
  doStuff(argument)
, 1000, "foo"
```

It would be much nicer to write:

  `_.timeout 1000, "foo", (argument) -> doStuff argument`

Do you think it's worth considering? It's pure syntactic sugar, but callbacks placed at the end of the argument list make a lot more sense...

title: Each doesn't execute callbacks when wrapped
body:
I recently upgraded to v3.1.0 and i noticed that the each method has broken when using it via a lodash wrapper. 

I also tested these in the console on the lodash website. Perhaps there's a change I'm unaware of but to break the functionality of each seems weird! 
##### Not Working

``` javascript
_([1,2,4,5,6,9]).each(function(c) { 
  console.log('hi')
})
```
#### Working

``` javascript
_.each([1,2,4,5,6,9], function(c) { 
  console.log('hi')
})
```

However, is there a way chaining could be handled (to benefit from lazy evaluation), such as via a function that takes a collection and an array of functions to chain? Does this exist or would it be something worth adding?

title: Uncaught ReferenceError: global is not defined
body:
It is not save to rely on `global` being available in browserified bundles (i.e. users may choose to [disable insertion of global variables](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify#var-b--browserifyfiles-or-opts) to keep the bundle minimal.

In case browserify (or webpack) did not expose a `global` variable [support.js](https://github.com/lodash/lodash-node/blob/master/modern/support.js#L10) throws an error saying

```
Uncaught ReferenceError: global is not defined
```

I am not sure what the right approach would be to solve this issue. I would probably check for `window` as a global variable because that should (_?_) always be available in DOM environments.

title: support _.uniq to lazy chaining
Possibility to use a callback with _.findWhere
body:
It would be really nice to use a callback with _.findWhere. My situation is as such:

``` coffeescript
obj = {key: val, deepKey: {deepCheck: deepVal}}

arr = [...] #lots of objects similar to obj 
```

and I want to perform this check:

``` coffeescript
foundObj = _.findWhere arr, (obj) -> obj.key is myVal and obj.deepKey.deepCheck is myOtherVal
```

So instead, to get around this, I have to do this:

``` coffeescript
foundObj = (_.filter arr, (obj) -> obj.key is myVal and obj.deepKey.deepCheck is myOtherVal)[0]
```

Since I know there will only be one matching object, using findWhere would be more convenient.

_.omit with _.isEmpty not work?
body:
amazing work!

``` javascript
var testObj = {
  a : 1,
  b : "",
}
_.isEmpty(testObj.b)  // => true
_.omit(testObj, _.isEmpty)  // => not work!  it delete everything 
```

but `_.isNull` and `_.isUndefined` works: 

``` javascript
var testObj = {
  a : 1,
  c : null,
}
_.omit(testObj, _.isNull)  // => works!

var testObj = {
  a : 1,
  d : undefined,
}
_.omit(testObj, _.isUndefined)  // => works!

```

title: Lodash 3 doesn't sort negative numbers properly
body:
This used to work in the previous version:

``` js
    L = require('lodash');

    waiting = [ {
        identifier: 'old-job',
        priority: 1,
        createdAt: -13155021680.648 },
      { identifier: 'medium-job',
        priority: 1,
        createdAt: -13155021821.845 },
      { identifier: 'young-job',
        priority: 1,
        createdAt: -13155022097.785 } ];

    console.log(L(waiting).sortBy(['priority', 'createdAt']).first());
    console.log(L(waiting).sortBy(['priority', 'createdAt']).last());
```

Changing the createdAt between positive and negative doesn't change the result.

Minified lodash is invalid javascript
body:
Including lodash in my project, I get:
`Uncaught SyntaxError: Unexpected token ILLEGAL`

Generated at `lodash.min.js:2055`

Seems the minified version changes all the quotes to double quotes, resulting in some triple quotes:

```
'"': """,
```

If changed to

```
'"': '"',
```

or

```
'"': "\"",
```

allows it to work.

title: _.findWhere not working with complex source
Consider renaming value() to run() for clarity
body:
Before version 3.0.0, the name `value()` made sense for the name of the function to extract the "one, true, unchanging value" from a chained sequence wrapper.

However, with the introduction of lazy evaluation in 3.0.0 the chained sequence wrapper no longer represents _one_ value and instead represents a "sequence of actions that may be repeatedly applied" (quoting the changelog). The example in the changelog of using `value()` to repeatedly invoke `push()` on an array is an excellent example of why the term "value" is outdated: a chained sequence wrapper may correspond to an infinite number of values.

Most people will expect code that calls `value()` to return the same value every time - whereas code that calls `run()`, `evaluate()` or `execute()` is obviously doing work each time and may return different results. By renaming `value()` to something that more closely corresponds to what it does - "executes the chained sequence" (quoting the documentation) - potential confusion might be avoided.

title: memoize() cache iteration
body:
In the change notes for memoize(), there's the following:

Made _.memoize cache implement the ES Map interface

It appears that as a result of this, the cache is no longer iterable; that is, the Map interface appears to be all that it implements.  If this is indeed the case, then given that this is a reduction in functionality, i.e. previously one could iterate the cache, but that seems now to no longer be possible, then a bit more in the release notes for this section would be helpful.

title: Error with _.find in 3.0.0?
Link to Changelog and other wiki pages from main README. Fixes #875
Chaining `map` and `reverse` returns unmodified array.
body:
When upgrading to 3.0.0 I had trouble with a code block very similar to 

``` javascript
_([{a: 1}, {a: 2}, {a: 3}, null])
  .map(function(v) { return v && v.a })
  .compact()
  .reverse()
  .value()
```

resulting in `[1, 2, 3, null]`, where I had expected `[3, 2, 1]`.

Comparing this example with the following you'll see that while the values can change the order and index will remain the same.

``` javascript
// returns [1, 2, 3, null], expected [null, 3, 2, 1]
_([1, 2, 3, null]).map(_.identity).reverse().value()

// returns [1, 2, 3, null], expected [3, 2, 1]
_([1, 2, 3, null]).map(_.identity).compact().reverse().value()
```

While a full ChangeLog would be nice, at least documenting compatibility issues from 2.2 to 2.4 and 2.4 to 3.0 would be helpful for those considering upgrading.

Thanks for lodash-- I use it nearly daily!

title: handle the sort order for sortByAll
body:
I created for a complete mixin lodash 2.4.1 to sort on multiple fields in ascending or descending order. I wanted to propose this feature for the 3.0, so I added with tests

Sorting behaves the same way as _.sortBy (). Reverse () and detects how many times the same values have changed their indexes.

To select the sort order, add a '+' or '-' before the name of the field:

``` javascript
_.sortByAll(collection, ['-a', '+b']);
```

title: Getting root object
body:
I was looking at lodash's source, and saw that you get root by comparing multiple values.

Is there any reason why you'd avoid using: `var root = Function('return this')();` 
(or a safer variation like: `var root = (function(){}).constructor('return this')();`)?

Both examples work in strict and loose mode. According to MDN, `Function.constructor` has been available since the initial JS version, so I'm assuming it works in older environments (haven't tested yet).

Would this fail to give the correct root object under any condition or in any environment? It seems like the most reliable way to get the root object in a system-agnostic way.

I'd like to do a feature request to expose root, either as a property (`_.root` or `_.ROOT`) or as a utility (`_.root()`  or `_.getRoot()`).
